qas.question: What is often considered valuable for generating a new set of philosophical problems?
What type of control do communitarians tend to support?
What type of economic and social policies do Communitarians tend to support?

answers.text: policies which encourage the growth of social capital

qas.question: What is valuable for creating greater local control?

plausible_answers.text: greater local control as well as economic and social policies which encourage the growth of social capital.

qas.question: What does political theory tend to support in communities?

plausible_answers.text: economic and social policies which encourage the growth of social capital.

qas.question: What type of policies do individuals support?

plausible_answers.text: the (distinct) criticisms of liberal political theory made by Michael Walzer, Michael Sandel and Charles Taylor

qas.question: What did a clash of perspective develop around?

plausible_answers.text: other communitarians (such as Alasdair MacIntyre and Daniel A. Bell)

qas.question: Who argues that individuals should have political focus?

context: Another debate developed around <b6_0>the (distinct) criticisms of liberal political theory made by Michael Walzer, Michael Sandel and Charles Taylor<b6_0/>. <a0_0><b3_0>The liberal-communitarian debate<b3_0/><a0_0/> is often considered valuable for generating a new set of philosophical problems, rather than a profound and illuminating clash of perspective.These and <b7_0>other communitarians (such as Alasdair MacIntyre and Daniel A. Bell)<b7_0/> argue that, contra liberalism, communities are prior to individuals and therefore should be the center of political focus. Communitarians tend to support <a1_0><b4_0>greater local control<a1_0/> as well as <b5_0>economic and social <a2_0>policies which encourage the growth of social capital<a2_0/>.
